track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Tax Tips
track.annotation: The end of the year brings a reminder that tax time approaches. Changes in the tax code means some adjustments will likely be necessary for many Oklahomans. IRS Spokesman, David Stell, joined us to give us details.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Lawmakers Charged
track.annotation: Felony bribery charges have been filed against a State Representative and a former State Senator.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Census Data
track.annotation: According to the 2010 Census, Oklahoma's population is nearly four million. Census figures will be sued to calculate the distribution of more than four hundred billion dollars in annual federal aid to our state.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Sen. Brian Bingman
track.annotation: When the state Equalization Board releases its final estimate of state revenue in February, it will be up to lawmakers to make those numbers add up. Senate President Pro-Tem Designate, Brian Bingmam, spoke about the financial difficulties facing the next legislature.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Equalization Board
track.annotation: State leaders, including Gov. Brad Henry, have voted to cut taxes for the state's top income earners for 2012.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Tulsa Fire and Accidents
track.annotation: Due to funding concerns, the city council in Tulsa is considering a cost recovery program that will allow first responders to bill motorists at fault in vehicle accidents.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Newmaker Interview with David Blatt
track.annotation: With the announcement that Oklahoma will face a revenue shortfall of $226 million in the 2011-12 fiscal year, David Blatt with the Oklahoma Policy Institute, joined us to talk about the impact of the budget shortfall.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Equalization Preview
track.annotation: State treasurer Scott Meacham announced that Oklahoma will face a revenue shortfall of $226 million in the 2011-12 fiscal year. The revenue report indicates that a trigger will be reached that will require a further reduction in taxes.

track.title: Okla
track.ov:subtitle: START Treaty
track.annotation: The U.S. Senate continues debate on the START Treaty with Russia. Some Republicans, including Oklahoma Senator Jim Inhofe, object to the debate being held during the current “lame-duck” session of Congress. Inhofe believes the debate should be postponed until next year.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Regents Agenda
track.annotation: The State Regents for Higher Education are asking lawmakers for a five-and-a-half percent increase in funding.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Savings
track.annotation: Tucked away inside the Will Rogers Building at the State Capitol Complex, a couple of state employees at Central Services are working to meet an important deadline. Beginning in January, they will visit with city managers across the state about a new program they believe will save Oklahoma taxpayers millions of dollars a year.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Water Plan
track.annotation: A comprehensive water plan being developed for the state is still a year away. At least one lawmaker, State Representative Jerry Ellis, is prepared to tackle water issues in the upcoming legislative session.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Tax Package and David Greenwell Interview
track.annotation: David Greenwell, a certified public accountant, joined us to talk about the impact the tax cut package will have on taxpayers.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Coburn on Tax Package
track.annotation: The U.S. Senate is expected to vote on the tax cut compromise by Wednesday evening. While the measure faces opposition in the House, final passage is still expected. Sen. Tom Coburn, (R) Oklahoma, is at the center of the debate over taxes and deficits.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: State Revenue and Scott Meacham Interview
track.annotation: Oklahoma’s economy is recovering, but at a slow pace. State revenue collections are up from last year, but are short of projections by almost ten million dollars. We talk with State Treasurer Scott Meacham about the latest figures.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: House Firings
track.annotation: Sixteen more jobs have been eliminated at the Oklahoma House of Representatives, due to budget cuts. House Speaker-designate, Kris Steele, said twelve fulltime and four part-time positions have been cut. These terminations come just one week after eleven other House staff members were fired, including the House Fiscal Director.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Indian Law Enforcement
track.annotation: Law enforcement jurisdiction on Indian Lands remains complicated. Cross-deputizing has helped in the last few years, but when a crime occurs at a casino or at another Indian-owned facility, deciding which agency has jurisdiction can still be an issue.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: AARP Happy
track.annotation: In an effort to keep fully funding Medicare reimbursement payments to doctors, Congress will use money intended to finance the healthcare program. In our Newsmaker Interview, we’re joined by the Interim Director for AARP Oklahoma, John Reinhart.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: House Caucus
track.annotation: The House Democratic Caucus has rejected President Obama’s tax deal with Republicans. Oklahoman Congressman Dan Boren was there for the vote, and he joined us by phone to talk about the decision.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Agency Consolidation
track.annotation: In the upcoming legislative session, a number of state agencies, boards, and commissions may face elimination or consolidation. Republicans say such a move could save the state ten-million dollars.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Fallin and Chamber
track.annotation: The revenue shortfall in the state budget is the focus of the upcoming legislative session. At their annual Public Affairs Forum, the State Chamber of Commerce reminded the Governor-elect and other legislative leaders that they believe less government spending and low taxes are the keys to economic development.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Republican Rift
track.annotation: A group of Republicans and members of the Tea Party, arrived in Bartlesville with a message for the leaders of the Oklahoma House of Representatives.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: House Schism
track.annotation: According to published reports, a schism within the Republican Party in the Oklahoma House of Representatives appears to be developing. Public battles on the Internet, and in press releases, illustrate the differing opinions between social and fiscal conservatives.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Extremist Legislation and Live Interview
track.annotation: The Presidents of the Oklahoma City Chamber of Commerce and the Tulsa chamber of Commerce believe extremist legislation is hurting Oklahoma's reputation for business. In our "newsmaker interview," OKC Chamber President Roy Williams says Oklahoma often loses out on the chance to attract new business because of some "extremist" comments made by some legislators.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Air Quality Study
track.annotation: The state may file a lawsuit over a plan by the Environmental Protection Agency to control air quality in national parks and other federal lands. Utility customers in Oklahoma may face rate hikes if the EPA rejects the state's plan to improve air quality.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: IRS Refunds
track.annotation: More than twelve-hundred Oklahomans are in line to get a refund from Uncle Sam, just in time for the holidays.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: New Legislature and Chris Benge Interview
track.annotation: Dozens of new house and senate members will take their seats when the Legislative Session begins in February. Former Speaker of the House, Chris Benge, is leaving office, and he gave us his perspective on the challenges facing Oklahoma lawmakers.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Broken Arrow Crime Watch
track.annotation: An anti-crime program in Broken Arrow is proving to be a model for communities around the nation and the world.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: ONR Extra Food Safety
track.annotation: Oklahoma U.S. Senator Tom Coburn is blocking a bill that supporters say will enhance food inspections and make the nation's food supply safer. In this ONR Extra, we hear Sen. Coburn’s reasons for his opposition to the bill, and the response from another lawmaker who supports the legislation.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Sheriff Software
track.annotation: Tulsa County sheriffs deputies are the first in the state to have access to technology that shares information with enforcement agencies from across the state and the nation.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: State Budget Live Interview
track.annotation: The state legislature convenes in February 2011, and Oklahoma is facing another huge budget shortfall. David Blatt with the Oklahoma Policy Institute says finding the money to fill the budget gap will be very difficult because the federal stimulus dollars, as well as the state's "rainy day funds," were used last year.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Sen. Brian Bingman
track.annotation: A live interview with Oklahoma Senate President Pro Tem Designate, Sen. Brian Bingman, on the budget issues facing the legislature in the next session.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Swearing-In
track.annotation: The new members of the Oklahoma House and Senate take their oaths of office.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Medical Examiner Protest
track.annotation: A small group of people held a protest on the south steps of the state Capitol, demanding a new law to force changes at the Medical Examiners office. The group charges the M.E.’s office regularly makes mistakes that allow murderers to remain free, and forces families of victims to launch their own investigations into what really happened to their loved ones.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Kris Steele Interview
track.annotation: A discussion with the new Speaker of the Oklahoma House of Representatives about the budget challenges facing the state.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Tax Credits
track.annotation: A House sub-committee is reviewing some of the more than $5.8-billion in tax credits, exemptions and rebates that state government passes out each year to business and industry. The goal is to set up a system to determine which of those tax breaks are actually providing benefit to the state.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Fallin Economic Team
track.annotation: Governor-Elect Mary Fallin has chosen her new economic development team. It includes a former state lawmaker, an official from a top aerospace company, and a banker.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Fallin and Chamber of Commerce
track.annotation: The Governor-elect says she has a "lot of work to do" to get ready to take over the reins of state government. Mary Fallin spoke to a group of State Chamber of Commerce members, and made it clear to them that they were very important to her success, as well as to the success of the state as a whole.
